raw_text:
Gender: Female

Age: 65

MRN: 775170

Diagnosis: Chronic viral hepatitis C

History and Physical:

First Visit  28th June 2024

Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today? What brings you here?

Patient: Doctor, I have been feeling very weak lately.

Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any other symptoms?

Patient: Yes, Ive had swelling in both my legs and abdominal distension since 2019. Recently, I also

had black-colored stool (melena).

Doctor: That sounds concerning. Do you have any history of liver disease or hepatitis?

Patient:  Yes,  I  was  diagnosed  with  hepatitis  B  in  2019  and  took  treatment  for  three  months.  After

that, I was managing my condition with medications.

Doctor: Understood. Have you had any episodes of vomiting blood (hematemesis) or jaundice?

Patient: No, I haven't had hematemesis or jaundice, but I do have ascites that responds to diuretics.

Doctor: Have you had significant weight loss, fevers, or night sweats?

Patient: No, none of those.

Doctor: Have you ever needed a blood transfusion?

Patient: Yes, Ive had five pints of blood transfused.

Doctor: I see. What medications are you currently taking?

Patient:  I  take  Cap  Nexum  40mg,  Tab  Spiromide  40mg,  Tab  Carveda  3.125mg,  and  Tab  Rifaxa

550mg.

Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Now, let me examine you. [Performs examination]

(cid:9)CNS: Conscious, well-oriented (GCS 15/15)

(cid:9)CVS: Normal heart sounds (S1 + S2 + 0)

(cid:9)Respiratory: Normal breath sounds (bilateral vesicular breathing)

 (cid:9)GIT: Abdomen soft, non-tender, non-distended

Doctor: Lets review your test results.

Investigations:

(cid:9)Endoscopy  (04/05/24):  Three  small  columns  of  esophageal  varices  (EV)  without  recent  bleeding,

severe pangastritis with multiple nodules and ulcers, portal hypertension.

(cid:9)Ultrasound  Abdomen  (03/06/24):  Cirrhotic  liver,  portal  hypertension,  mild  to  moderate  ascites,  no

focal lesions.

(cid:9)CT  Scan  (10/06/24):  Cirrhotic  liver  with  left  lobe  hypertrophy,  no  arterialized  lesions,  portal  vein

thrombosis, moderate splenomegaly.

Lab Results:

Test(cid:9)22/03/24(cid:9)07/06/24

Hemoglobin (HB)(cid:9)8.7(cid:9)-

TLC(cid:9)6.3(cid:9)-

Platelets (PLT)(cid:9)64(cid:9)-

Total Bilirubin (T-BIL)(cid:9)-(cid:9)0.8

ALT/AST(cid:9)-(cid:9)23/25

ALP(cid:9)-(cid:9)75

Albumin(cid:9)-(cid:9)3.5

Creatinine(cid:9)1.27(cid:9)1.03

Sodium (Na)(cid:9)125(cid:9)-

Potassium (K)(cid:9)4.1(cid:9)-

INR(cid:9)-(cid:9)1.1

AFP(cid:9)-(cid:9)1.9

PIVKA II(cid:9)-(cid:9)31.77

MELD Na Score(cid:9)-(cid:9)8 points

Doctor:  Based  on  your  history,  examination,  and  tests,  we  suspect  Hepatitis  B  or  C-related

decompensated chronic liver disease (DCLD).

 Patient: Whats the next step, doctor?

Doctor:  We  need  to  complete  your  HBV  and  HCV  PCR  tests.  Liver  transplant  is  the  definitive

treatment,  but  its  not  immediately  necessary.  Your  son  is  available  as  a  donor,  and  we  have

explained the donor criteria to him. We will monitor your condition closely.

Management Plan:

1.(cid:9)Complete pending lab tests (HBV and HCV PCR).

2.(cid:9)Submit a CD of the CT scan to Interventional Radiology.

3.(cid:9)Follow up with hepatology in three weeks.

4.(cid:9)Start Qalsan D once daily.

Follow-up Visit  11th October 2024

Doctor: Welcome back. Have you had any new symptoms since your last visit?

Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing nausea and loose stools.

Doctor: I see. Let me confirmare you still taking your medications?

Patient: Yes, I am currently taking:

(cid:9)Spironolactone/furosemide 20/50mg

(cid:9)Iron tablets (Fefol)

(cid:9)Qalsan (Vitamin D)

(cid:9)Carvedilol 3.125mg twice daily

(cid:9)Ensure (nutritional supplement) three times daily

(cid:9)Omeprazole 40mg

Doctor: Let's do a quick examination.

(cid:9)General Appearance: Normal-looking, middle-aged woman

(cid:9)CNS: Alert and oriented (GCS 15/15)

(cid:9)CVS: Normal heart sounds (S1 + S2 + 0)

(cid:9)GIT: Soft, non-tender abdomen

(cid:9)Respiratory: Normal breath sounds

 Investigations:

(cid:9)Ultrasound  Abdomen  (29/06/24):  Chronic  liver  disease  with  moderate  splenomegaly,  mild  ascites,

no discrete focal hepatic lesions.

(cid:9)CT  Scan  (29/06/24):  Bland  thrombus  in  the  portal  vein,  dilated  portal  and  splenic  veins,  bilateral

renal cysts.

Lab Results:

Test(cid:9)22/03/24(cid:9)07/06/24(cid:9)24/08/24

Hemoglobin (HB)(cid:9)8.7(cid:9)-(cid:9)9.1

TLC(cid:9)6.3(cid:9)-(cid:9)14.5

Platelets (PLT)(cid:9)64(cid:9)-(cid:9)58,000

Total Bilirubin (T-BIL)(cid:9)-(cid:9)0.8(cid:9)1.2

ALT/AST(cid:9)-(cid:9)23/25(cid:9)41

ALP(cid:9)-(cid:9)75(cid:9)79

Albumin(cid:9)-(cid:9)3.5(cid:9)-

Creatinine(cid:9)1.27(cid:9)1.03(cid:9)1.13

Sodium (Na)(cid:9)125(cid:9)-(cid:9)132

Potassium (K)(cid:9)4.1(cid:9)-(cid:9)4.67

INR(cid:9)-(cid:9)1.1(cid:9)1.28

AFP(cid:9)-(cid:9)1.9(cid:9)-

PIVKA II(cid:9)-(cid:9)31.77(cid:9)-

MELD Na Score(cid:9)-(cid:9)8 points(cid:9)8 points

Doctor:  Your  condition  remains  stable,  but  there  is  some  confusion  about  whether  you  have

Hepatitis B or C. We need further testing to confirm.

Patient: What should I do next?

Doctor: Heres the plan:

1.(cid:9)Colonoscopy to evaluate chronic diarrhea.

2.(cid:9)HBsAg, AFP, and HCV PCR to clarify hepatitis status.

 3.(cid:9)Ultrasound abdomen and plan an endoscopy.

4.(cid:9)Medications:

o(cid:9)Spironolactone 100mg once daily

o(cid:9)Calcium carbonate/Vitamin D once daily

o(cid:9)Carvedilol 3.125mg twice daily

o(cid:9)Multivitamin once daily

5.(cid:9)Follow-up in six weeks.

Doctor: If you experience worsening symptoms, please return earlier.

Patient: Thank you, doctor.

DiagnosticConclusions: Hepatitis B or C-related decompensated chronic liver disease (DCLD)

ImagingFindings: Endoscopy: Three small columns of esophageal varices without recent bleeding, severe pangastritis with multiple nodules and ulcers, portal hypertension
Ultrasound Abdomen: Cirrhotic liver, portal hypertension, mild to moderate ascites, no focal lesions
CT Scan: Cirrhotic liver with left lobe hypertrophy, no arterialized lesions, portal vein thrombosis, moderate splenomegaly
Ultrasound Abdomen: Chronic liver disease with moderate splenomegaly, mild ascites, no discrete focal hepatic lesions
CT Scan: Bland thrombus in the portal vein, dilated portal and splenic veins, bilateral renal cysts

SummaryNarrative.ClinicalCourseProgression: Patient has been experiencing weakness, swelling in legs, abdominal distension, and black-colored stool since 2019.
SummaryNarrative.DiagnosticJourney: Patient diagnosed with hepatitis B in 2019, currently suspected of having hepatitis C-related decompensated chronic liver disease.
SummaryNarrative.TreatmentResponse: Patient is on multiple medications and has had blood transfusions.
SummaryNarrative.OngoingConcerns: Need for further testing to confirm hepatitis status and monitor liver condition.
